Award.AwardTitle: Meeting: Auxin 2016: Haitang Bay, China, 20-25 October 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration: The Auxin 2016 meeting will be held October 20-25, 2016 in Haitang Bay, Sanya, China. The plant hormone auxin is an essential regulator of almost every aspect of plant growth and development. The auxin field is an active and rapidly developing area in plant biology and is increasingly relying on high level integration of diverse approaches with computational models and bioinformatics. Coupled with recent advances in synthetic biology there has been a resurgence of interest in broadening our understanding of auxin biology. The objective of this conference is to bring together a broad array of experts to enhance the international dialogue on critical issues relating to auxin biology. This conference will contribute to the enhancement and improvement of scientific and/or educational activities by bringing together a leading group of International and US researchers. Participation in this meeting provides a significant training experience for young career scientists who represent the future of science in the US. In addition, this meeting will provide the foundation for international collaborations between researchers in the US and elsewhere. The Auxin 2016 meeting will include oral presentations by invited speakers and from those selected from submitted abstracts, poster sessions, and lightning talks by junior investigators. The requested funds will be used to off-set registration costs for up to 30 US early career scientists and to provide funds for one junior faculty member who is an invited presenter. The organizers will prioritize support for underrepresented groups and women with NSF funds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 5th international conference on auxin research (Auxin2016) was held at the Hotel Sheraton in Sanya, Hainan Island, China from 20-24 October 2016. It was co-organized by two American faculty members (Zhenbiao Yang, UC Riverside and Jennifer Nemhauser, U. Washington) in addition to Dolf Weijers (Wageninen U., The Netherlands). The goals of this meeting were all met or exceeded, including: (1) promoting rapid dissemination of new knowledge, (2) nucleating global collaborations that integrate expertise across diverse disciplines and study systems, and (3) encouraging interaction among established and junior researchers. Since 2000, the Auxin conference has been held every 4 years (Corsica, Crete, Marrakech, Hawaii), and has built up a reputation as a platform to debut high impact, unpublished work, as well as an opportunity to launch collaborations across disciplines. 27 leading scientists from 11 countries were invited speakers (8 from the US, 1 a junior faculty member) with a number of talks selected from abstracts going to US junior faculty, postdocs or graduate students. Seven travel awards were dispensed to US junior faculty or trainees. A number of publications have directly resulted from the meeting, broadening the dissemination of knowledge beyond the attendees. These include a review article (Vernoux and Robert, Development 2017 PMID: 28196801) and an upcoimg special issue of the Journal of Experimental Botany. The organizers of the next meeting were also selected and include Lucia Strader, a recently promoted Associate Professor at Washington University St. Louis.
